intro: Aplectrum myrtifolium, commonly known as the myrtle-leaved bellflower, is a flowering plant native to parts of eastern North America. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, pale blue to violet flowers. The plant has opposite, ovate to elliptic leaves with a slightly hairy texture. It typically grows in moist, shaded woodlands and thrives in well-drained soils. Aplectrum myrtifolium is valued for its ornamental appeal and ecological importance as a nectar source for pollinators.
